## Variable Review Variables store information. The variable is defined on the left hand side of the expression, and the value is set on the right side. ![](https://curriculum.code.org/media/uploads/vardefine.PNG) We would read this expression like so: *The variable `score` gets the value 3 ## Counter Pattern with Event | Name | Code (Block) | Code (Text) | | ------------- | ------------- | ------------- | | Counter Pattern with Event | ![](https://images.code.org/fb4f1477d57648cb4bde14c2b710e196-image-1600883760296.png) |
`var myVar = 0;`

`onEvent("id", "click", function() {`
    `myVar = myVar + 1;`
`});`
| The model could be read like so: *The variable `myVar` gets the value 0. When the onEvent is triggered by a click the variable is updated. `myVar` now gets the current value of `myVar` and adds one to it. The new value is then stored in `myVar`.* ### How does it work? When the event is triggered, the variable is updated. The current value of the variable is increased or decreased by a set amount. The new value is stored in the variable. ### Examples ![](https://curriculum.code.org/media/uploads/counter_pattern_with_event.gif)
*The variable `score` gets the value 0. When the onEvent is triggered by a click on the button, the variable is updated. `score` now gets the current value of `score` and adds one to it. The new value is then stored in `score`. The score is then displayed on the screen.* ![](https://curriculum.code.org/media/uploads/counter_pattern_with_event2.gif)
*The variable `score` gets the value 50. When the onEvent is triggered by a click on the button, the variable is updated. `score` now gets the current value of `score` and subtracts three from it. The new value is then stored in `score`. The score is then displayed on the screen.*
